quote: Captain's Log, Stardate 46041.1.   We have located the U.S.S.   Yosemite, a Starfleet science   vessel sent to the Igo Sector to   observe a remote plamsa streamer.   The ship has not been heard from   in several days.
Magnify.
The last report we have says they   were observing the streamer at   medium range. Maybe they went   in for a closer look... got more   than they bargained for.
Hail them.
No response.
Life signs?
Our scanners cannot penetrate the   plasma streamer's distortion   field.
Can we tractor the vessel out?
No, sir -- the ionic interference   is too heavy.
I'll take a shuttle.
Too risky -- you could be pulled   in, too.       Bridge to Engineering -- Geordi,   can we beam an Away Team onto the   science ship?
We can beam them over there,   Captain -- but with all this   interference, we might not get   a positive lock to bring them   back.
Commander... what if we bridged   our Transporter system with   theirs? It might be enough to   cut through the ionic field.
To do that, we'd have to activate   the Yosemite's Transporters by   remote...
No problem, sir. I can   reconfigure their controller to   accept commands from here.
Good idea, Reg.       Captain, I think we can do it.   We're gonna bridge the two   Transporter systems.
Acknowledged. Meet Commander   Riker in Transporter Room Three.
Aye sir.    (to Barclay, on the     move)   Barclay -- I'll need a systems'   engineer on this Away Team.
I'll ask Ensign Dern to join you.
I meant you, Barclay.
Shouldn't I stay here and set up   the remote link?
Dern can handle that. Let's go.
Status, Mister O'Brien?
You're in for a bumpy ride,   Commander.
I'll have to send you over one   at a time... because of band-width   limitations. And the transport   cycle will take a bit longer.
How much longer?
Four, five seconds... about twice   the normal time.
What do you... what exactly do   you mean by a bumpy ride?
There may be a small amount of   static charge accumulation.   You'll feel a bit of tingling --   nothing to worry about.
Let's do it.
Engaging system interlock...       Pattern buffers synchronized...
Phase transition coils at   stand-by...       Energizing.
He's there.
Engaging interlock...       Buffers synched...
Energizing.
I'll go next.
Engaging interlock...       Buffers synched...
Whoa, wait a minute...       I'm reading an ionic fluctuation   in the matter stream... No   problem.
Okay... Energizing.
Barclay.
Aye sir...
Engaging interlock...       Buffers in synch...
Phase coils...
I'm sorry -- I can't do this.
You were faced with a difficult   transport, Reg. Anyone would have   been apprehensive in that   situation.
Tell that to Commander La Forge   and the rest of the Away Team...
I'm sure they understand. As soon   as you feel up to it, you can   probably still join them --
No.
Reg... is there something you're   not telling me?
Actually, this isn't the first   time I've been... apprehensive.       Every single time I've had to do   it, I've had a certain feeling   of... I guess you could call it...       ... mortal terror.
I see. How long have you had this   fear of transporting?
Why have you kept it a secret?
Why? My career in Starfleet would   be over, that's why.
I doubt that.

I usually manage to avoid it   somehow. You wouldn't believe   how many hours I've logged on   shuttlecrafts...       The thought of being deconstructed   molecule by molecule. It's more   than I can stand...
Ever since I was a child, I've   been scared to death that if I   ever dematerialized... I wouldn't   come back whole again.       I know it sounds crazy.
There's nothing crazy about it,   Reg -- you are being taken apart   molecule by molecule. You're not   the first person to have anxiety   about transporting.
We can desensitize you to this   type of fear. It's a slow and   gradual process... but it works.
It does... how?
Well... the first step might   be a relaxation technique. Like   Plexing.
Plexing?
It's a Betazoid method. The next   time you feel nervous about   transporting, you would stimulate   a neural pressure point -- like   this...
There's a nerve cluster just   behind the carotid artery -- it   stimulates the part of the brain   that releases natural endorphins.
Plexing... sounds easy enough...
You know, I feel better already.   I can do this.
Reg... there's no need to rush...
No, no, no. We've talked before   about confronting my fears. "The   best way out is through." You   said that once, remember?
I suppose I did...
I'm going to beam over there.   I can do it.
No sign of survivors. No sign   of a anyone.
Maybe they abandoned ship.
Unlikely. Both escape pods are   still on board.
Well, there was an explosion in   here. We know that much.
Any idea what caused it?
I've ruled out a reactor core   failure... and there's no sign   of a systems overload.
Blast analysis indicates the   explosion originated...
...here. In the center of this   transport chamber.
How is that possible? The   Transporter is still functional.
Could someone have beamed an   explosive device aboard?
Commander Riker...
Lieutenant Joshua Kelly -- he   was the ship's engineer.
How did he die?
There's evidence of burns... but   they don't look serious enough   to have killed him... I'm going   to have to take him back for an   autopsy.
You're sure about this, sir?
I'm sure. Please proceed.
This'll only take a minute...
Should be a smooth ride over, sir.
Good... good...
I know how you feel about this,   sir.
You... you're afraid of   transporting?
No -- of arachnids.       Spiders. Sickening, crawly little   things, don't you think? All   those legs...
They've never bothered me.

A few years back, I was called   in to re-route an emitter array   at a Starbase on Zayra Four.   Turns out the entire system was   infested with Talarian hook   spiders.       Ever see a Talarian hook spider?
Their legs are half a meter long.       Anyway, I had a choice. Do I walk   away and let the emitter blow   itself to hell... or do I crawl   into a Jeffries Tube with twenty   hook spiders?
What happened?
It was the hardest thing I ever   did. But I got through it. After   that, I was never quite as afraid   of spiders.
Thanks...
Energizing.
Welcome aboard, Reg. Ready to   work?
Yes, sir.
Good. Start by downloading the   ship's science logs. Over   there...
Aye sir.
Still four members of the crew   unaccounted for. You come up with   anything?
I don't know how these fit in,   but... I found them near the   Transporter platform.
What are they?
They look like pieces of a   standard sample container.
Take them back to the ship. We'll   analyze them later.
Glad you could join us, Mister   Barclay.
Me too, sir.
The Ferengi are claiming two of   their freighters were destroyed   by a Cardassian warship in your   sector.
Is there any evidence to support   this?
Although I'm loathe to believe   the Ferengi about anything...   there was evidence of Cardassian   weapons.
If the Cardassians also attacked the   Yosemite... it could indicate   a large-scale movement into this   sector.
I have an Away Team aboard the   ship now. Their initial report   indicates an explosion on board.   But we're not sure if it was from   an attack...
How long until you'll know?
A few hours. If it does look like   the Cardassians, I'll contact you   immediately.
Very well.
Bridge to Captain Picard.
Yes, Mister Data?
The Away Team is returning to the   Enterprise.
Acknowledged. Have Commander   Riker join me in my Ready Room   as soon as he's on board.
Aye sir.
La Forge to Transporter Room   Three.
I'm ready to go.
Stand by, Commander.
Barclay to Enterprise...       One to beam back.
Stand by, sir.
You see, sir? That wasn't so bad,   was it?

Captain's Log, supplemental. Our   investigation has revealed there   was an explosion aboard the   Yosemite -- possibly the result   of an attack. We are still   analyzing data obtained by the   Away Team.
Mission logs... science logs...   medical logs -- they're all   completely scrambled. It looks   like the blast wiped out the   ship's core memory.
We could try to reconstitute the   data stream.
It's worth a try.
Commander... has anything...   strange ever happened to you   during transport?
Like what?
I don't know... anything out of   the ordinary...
Not really...
This looks hopeless -- we're not   gonna get anything from the   logs...
Maybe this broken sample   container I found can tell us   something...
Right...
Let's try to get this thing back   in one piece...
I mean -- have you ever seen   anything?
Where?
In the... during transport.
Sometimes my VISOR picks up   resonance patterns from the   matter-energy conversion. It's   actually kind of pretty.       Why?
Just wondering...
Reg -- what are you getting at?
Do you think you saw something   during transport?
When I was returning to the   Enterprise... I could've sworn   I saw something... in the matter   stream.
Something?

There was phased matter all   around... at first I thought it   was some kind of energy discharge.   But then it flew toward me... and   touched my arm...       But how could anything be in   there... the molecules flying   apart... half-phased... it's...
It's... impossible, isn't it?
We'd better check it out. When   we're done here, let's run a full   Transporter diagnostic. Alright?
Alright.
The confinement beam subsystems   check out. So do the phase   transition coils.
The pattern buffer's fine.
Emitter pad... targeting scanner   -- they're all running normally.   This system's clean... so is the   science vessel's.
There's a lot of energy floating   around in the beam. Maybe you   saw a surge in the matter stream.
Yeah...
I'll run a scan on the Heisenberg   compensators...
No... you've done more than enough   already, Chief...
No problem at all. Why don't you   give me a hand?
Maybe ignorance really is bliss...
Sir?
If I didn't know so much about   these things... maybe they   wouldn't scare me so much...

I can still remember the day in   Doctor Olafson's class on   Transporter Theory when he talked   about the body being converted   into billions of kiloquads of   data... zipping through   subspace... and I realized,   there's no margin for error. One   atom out of place and poof! You   never come back...       It's amazing people don't get lost   all the time.
With all due respect sir -- I've   been doing this for twenty-two   years, and I haven't lost anybody   yet.
Yes, but... you realize if these   imaging scanners are off by even   a thousandth of a percent --
That's why each pad has four   redundant scanners. If any one   scanner fails, the other three   take over.
How many Transporter accidents   have there been in the last ten   years, Reg? Two... three? What   about the millions of people who   transport every day without a   problem?
I've... I've heard about   problems... what about...   Transporter Psychosis?
Transporter Psychosis -- there   hasn't been a case of that in over   fifty years. Not since they   perfected multiplex pattern   buffers.
Transporting really is the safest   way to travel, Reg.
I want to take a closer look at   those burns.       Take a tissue sample.
Yes, Doctor.
Damage to the epidermis only...       Initiate a circulatory probe.
Doctor Crusher...
His heart is beating.
Cardio-stimulator -- now.
It's gone.
Neuro-electrical activity in the   cerebral cortex.
Nothing.
Now the respiratory system's   active. What the hell's going   on...
Endocrine system's functioning...   now the lymphatic system...   the pancreas...
Just water, please.
Thanks.
Water, ten degrees celsius.
Computer... access Starfleet   Medical Data Base. Tell me   about... describe the disorder   known as... Transporter Psychosis.
Transporter Psychosis was   diagnosed in the year   twenty-two-oh-nine by researchers   on Delinia Two --
No, no... stop. All I need is   the... what causes it?
It is caused by a breakdown of   neuro-chemical molecules during   transport, affecting the body's   motor functions, autonomic   systems, and the brain's higher   reasoning centers.
What are the symptoms?
Victims suffer from paranoid   delusions... multi-infarct   dementia... hallucinations...
Hallucinations? What kind of   hallucinations?
Victims experience somatic,   tactile and visual hallucinations,   accompanied by psychogenic   hysteria.
Peripheral symptoms include   sleeplessness... accelerated   heart-rate...
Diminished eyesight, leading to   acute myopia... painful spasms   in the extremities...
And in most cases, dehydration.
Computer... what is the treatment   for Transporter Psychosis?
There is no known treatment.
The autopsy showed residual   ionization in every one of   Lieutenant Kelly's systems.   I think that's what caused   the muscular and systemic   contractions.
Where did this ionization come   from?
There's evidence of electrical   burns on the victim's body...   as if she were exposed to ionized   gas... or high energy plasma.
Plasma? There's no way they   could've been exposed... unless   it was matter from the streamer...
Is there any evidence of a hull   breach... could plasma from the   streamer have found its way into   the ship?
No...    (gets an idea, to     Data)   Data, what's the report on that   broken sample container?
The analysis of the fragments is   not yet complete.
Captain -- if there's evidence   of similar ionization in those   fragments... it could mean they   tried to beam aboard material from   the streamer...
And if the plasma exploded... that   would explain a few things.       Let me know when the analysis   is complete.
Aye sir.
From the looks of these fracture   patterns, I'd say the explosive   force came from within the   container.
The container does show evidence   of residual ionization.       I believe your hypothesis was   correct. It was being used to   store high energy plasma.
So they were collecting samples   from the plasma streamer...       But they were using the proper   container. How could it have   exploded?
Perhaps we should try to recreate   their experiment to see what   happens when matter is beamed   aboard under similar conditions.
Good idea. Let's prepare a new   container.       Reg, I don't want to take any   chances -- start setting up a   level five containment field here   in Engineering.
Aye sir...
Are you having trouble with your   eyesight, Mister Barclay?
No... thank you.
May I have a word with you,   Geordi? It concerns Lieutenant   Barclay.
What is it?
He appears to be inordinately   preoccupied with his physiological   condition. I have seen him check   his pulse rate, as well as his   visual acuity several times in   the last twenty minutes.
Reg...
Yessir?
Are you alright?
Just fine, sir.
You look a little pale.
I do?
It's been a long couple of days,   Reg. Why don't you get some rest.   We've got everything under control   here.
I'll do that, sir. Thank you.
La Forge to Counselor Troi.
Go ahead, Commander.
Counselor... do you have a minute?
Lieutenant Barclay, I've been   calling you, why haven't you   responded --
Reg, what are you doing?
Walking.
I can see that. Where are you   going?
Nowhere. I just don't get to   these decks very often.       There's Stellar Cartography --   I thought that was on Deck Eleven.
Mister Barclay...
I was... I was having trouble   sleeping. I'm just trying to wear   myself out. That's a perfectly   normal thing to be doing, isn't   it?
Commander La Forge said you seemed   very nervous this morning.
I'm always nervous. Everyone   knows that.
He also mentioned that you said   you saw something in the   Transporter beam.
I was wrong. They checked the   Transporter and there wasn't...   there was nothing there. I   imagined the whole thing.
You don't sound very convinced   of that...
Counselor, I appreciate your   concern... but I'd rather not   continue this conversation.   I'm... I'm feeling perfectly fine.
Mister Barclay, you are exhausted   and highly agitated.
And I cannot allow a member of   this crew to endanger himself and   others. I think --
I'm not endangering anyone and   I wish you would --
I think it's in your best interest   to take a leave of absence.       Reg -- I'm temporarily relieving   you of duty.
Fine... fine... do what you have   to do, Counselor...
Computer... more birds.
End stress reduction program.
Water.
Specify temperature.
I don't care -- just give me   water!
Calm... stay calm...       Computer -- let's try music...   something soothing.
Barclay to Chief O'Brien.
O'Brien here.
I need your help. Would you   meet me in Transporter Room   Three... ?
Sir, begging your pardon -- but   couldn't this wait til morning?
No...
Chief... I've just... I've been   reviewing the transport logs...       What are these... energy   variations that keep appearing?   There was one when I transported   to the science ship... see?
They're just ionic fluctuations,   sir. A result of our interlock   with the Yosemite's transporter   system.
A fluctuation occurred while I   was inside the matter stream... ?
It's nothing to worry about, sir.
I need you to transport me to the   science ship... and directly back   again. And while I'm in the   beam... can you recreate one of   those ionic fluctuations... ?
I guess so... but if you don't   mind my asking, sir... what for?
I need to... Commander La Forge   wants some tricorder readings of   those fluctuations.
We can do it from right here.
No, I... the Transporter sensors   may not be sensitive enough...
I'm giving you an order, Mister   O'Brien.
Aye sir.
If you don't mind my making an   observation...       You forgot to bring a tricorder.
Either there's something in   there... or I'm going crazy.   I've got to know.       You can understand that, can't   you?
Yes sir, I can.
Stand by, sir...
I want you to wake the senior   staff.
Then I saw it again -- just twenty   minutes ago. The same exact thing   moving around in the Transporter   beam.
Let me get this straight -- you   think it was alive?
It was dark and distorted... and   it had what looked like... a   mouth...
A mouth?
I don't see anything wrong with   his arm.
Reg -- why did you wait so long   to tell anybody about your arm?
Well... I thought I was   hallucinating. I thought it   was... that I had... Transporter   Psychosis...

But now I know I don't. I know   what I saw in there... was real.       I was the only one to experience   an ionic fluctuation during   transport... maybe that explains   why that's why no one else saw   it.
We ran a full diagnostic on the   Transporter system yesterday,   Captain. It checked out fine.
Number One?
We've been conducting intensive   scans of the entire binary star   system. No sign of any life   forms.
Mister Barclay, I understand   you've been under a considerable   amount of strain the past couple   of days. Isn't it possible you   simply imagined --
I know what you're going to say,   sir. And I realize... I know I've   been acting strangely. But you've   got to believe me. I wouldn't   have called you in here if I   weren't absolutely certain.
Commander La Forge, get Chief   O'Brien -- take the Transporter   system apart piece by piece if   you have to.       Mister Worf -- maintain a level   three security alert until further   notice.
Aye, sir.
I'll run a micro-cellular scan   on Mister Barclay's arm. It'll   take some time -- but if there's   something wrong, I'll find it.
Keep me apprised. Dismissed.

I'm reading minute levels of   residual ionization in the   sub-dermal tissue of his left arm.       The patterns correspond exactly   to the ones we measured in   Lieutenant Kelly's body... and   in the sample container from the   science ship.       There's no question -- you've been   exposed to the same high energy   plasma they were.
So... something did happen to me   in the Transporter beam?

It's too early to draw   conclusions... you might've been   exposed to something on the   science ship. But you did say   something touched your left arm   during transport... and that's   where the ionization is   focused...
Does this ionization pose a threat   to Mister Barclay?
It might. I'll need to run a   base-pair correlation to look for   signs of DNA break-down.
Sir... Commander La Forge and I   were planning to recreate the   circumstances of the explosion   on the Yosemite... that might   give us some answers. Permission   to continue with the experiment?
Granted. Tell Chief O'Brien to   take all primary Transporters   off-line. I don't want to risk   any further... contaminations.   And make sure you take the   necessary safety precautions.
Aye sir.
I want you to wear this   monitoring-device. It'll signal   me at the slightest sign of   increased ionization.
Yes, Doctor.
Structural reinforcement is at   two hundred forty percent.
Activating containment field...
That should do it.       Okay, Reg -- we've locked onto   the coordinates of the plasma   streamer. You can beam aboard   a sample.
Aye sir.
Okay... what would they have done   first?
A standard analysis begins with   a resonance frequency scan.
Sounds like a good place to start.   Let's do it.
Initiating resonance sweep.   Frequency range at --
Check the containment field.
Field is at maximum limits, sir.   But it is holding.
My VISOR's picking up bio-magnetic   energy... highly complex   patterns...       I think these things are alive.   Reg...
Reg?
Reg!
Life forms?
That is correct. They appear to   be quasi-energy microbes that   exist within the distortion field   of the plasma streamer -- which   made them undetectable to our   sensors.
They didn't come out until we   tried to run the resonance   frequency scan. Apparently, they   didn't like it too much. They   reacted by shattering the sample   container.
Which caused a plasma explosion   similar to the one on the science   ship...
Exactly.       We think one or more of the   microbes may have gotten into the   Transporter system -- and are   still caught inside the buffer.   It probably explains what you saw   in there...
But... what I saw was much larger   than a microbe...
Normal spatial relationships, such   as size, are often distorted   within the matter stream.
Some of these microbes are also   in your body, Reg.
Inside me?
They were in Lieutenant Kelly's   body as well... that's what caused   the contractions during the   autopsy.
Is that what killed him?

Yes...       But now that we've identified the   microbes, we can start trying to   eliminate them. I'm going to run   a full spectrum antigen series...   if that doesn't work, I'll try   an imaging probe...
But... isn't there a way to...   to... to force these things out   of me?
The bio-filter should've screened   them out... but it didn't...
The microbes exist simultaneously   as both matter and energy. The   bio-filters cannot distinguish   them from the matter stream.
Right... but -- if we held Barclay   suspended in mid-transport... at   the point where matter starts to   lose molecular cohesion...
The molecules would begin to emit   nucleonic particles. We might   be able to derive a pattern the   computer could recognize...
... and reprogram the bio-filters   to screen out the microbes.       Reg, I think this'll work.
Suspend me... I don't like the   sound of that...
We'd have to hold you in there   for a while...
How long?
Thirty or forty seconds... it's   hard to tell. But I think it   would be safe...
But... if I'm in the matter stream   too long...
Your pattern would degrade to the   point where your signal would be   permanently lost.
Your pattern might degrade to the   point where your signal would be   permanently lost.
This has been the thing I've been   afraid of all my life... that I'd   go in and not come back...
But I guess... if I'm ever going   to confront my fear, it might   as well be now...
After fifteen seconds or so in   the beam, you may start to feel   lightheaded. Try to stay calm...   and it's important you don't   move around too much.
Right.
Initializing the back-up pattern   buffer. Holding at stand by...
You ready, Reg?
Energize.
Molecular resolution at sixty   percent... engaging static   mode... his pattern is locked and   holding...
Starting bio-filter scan...
Signal's holding...
The imaging scanners still aren't   isolating the microbes...
I'll try increasing molecular   dispersion...
But -- his signal resolution's   dropped to fifty-five percent...
Don't worry -- I can hold him   together...
His signal resolution's down to   fifty percent... we need to bring   him back...
I know, I know... just give me   one more second...       We need more dispersion...   increase phase-transition   frequency...
Aye, sir...
The imaging scanners are   actuating...
Got it... pattern acquisition...       Positive.
Programming bio-filter...
This won't hurt a bit, Reg...
I'm reading a ninety-two percent   increase in mass, sir!
Something's in the beam with   him...       Security to Transporter Room   Three!
I'm setting up a force field   around the chamber...
(to O'Brien, on the     move)   Drop the force field.
There are more of them in the   beam... you have to grab them   and hold on...
Reg, what happened?
When I saw there was more than   one of them... I thought... maybe   the other crew was trying the   same thing we were...
We were infected with   something... Lieutenant Kelly...   tried to reprogram the   bio-filter...
It looks like he increased   molecular dispersion past the   integrity point... your patterns   were lost in the beam.
The residual energy from the   plasma streamer... it must've   amplified the charge in the   buffer... enough to keep your   patterns from degrading...

Captain's Log, Stardate 46043.6.   The reprogrammed bio-filter was   effective in removing the alien   microbes from Mister Barclay and   the four crewmembers. The   microbes have been returned to   the plasma streamer.
Chief...
Lieutenant -- glad you could make   it.
You know, I think this is the   first time we've ever talked,   outside the Transporter Room.
Well... to be honest, I always   avoided you.
Why?
Because... you run the   Transporters, and I hate   transporters...
At least... I used to...
So what's in the box?
I thought you might like to meet   Christina.
Christina -- Lieutenant Barclay.
Your... pet spider.
Lycosa tarantula. Don't worry,   she won't bite.
It's... she's... very... large.
I found her on Titus Four...   almost stepped on her by accident.
I'll get us a couple of drinks.   Keep an eye on her, will you?
Sure...
Um... Chief...
